Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Capture and Use of Coal Mine Ventilation Air Methane (VAM)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project proposes to develop innovative technical solutions and products that reduce coal mine gas explosion. Methane explosion is the major cause of mining casualty and economic loss. The list of world coal mine explosion is a long and shocking one. Even today, 300 years after human?s initial mining of coal, methane explosion still kills thousands of miners each year worldwide. Developed naturally within coal seams, methane is known for explosion hazard and chemical neutrality, which makes it highly dangerous but difficult to remove. Although modern technologies have been developed to pre-release methane or to dilute it by ventilation, it is practically impossible to eliminate the threat due to frequently occurred gas bursts and accumulation. Due to economic concern, mine owners and managers hesitate to take prompt action in response to each gas alarm. Sometime, their hesitation proved to be deadly. Torrey Hills invented a technology that can effectively capture methane from ambient atmosphere and convert it to safe chemicals, and thus can reduce explosion risk and operation shutdown loss to coal mine owners. The main features of the technology are room-temperature and room-pressure operation, complementary to ventilation, attendance free, and portable.


The broader impact/commercial potential of this project includes not only addition of economic value to coal mine owners and operators, but also contribution to the overall society wealth in a broader sense by reducing life loss and improving environmental protection. The world coal market is estimated to be $400-600 billion per year. According to World Coal Association, the direct economic loss caused by coal methane explosion is over $10 billion worldwide each year. Nevertheless, the broader indirect costs are difficult to measure, including loss of life, hardship on the affected families, disruption to the local business, legal burden on the companies, and associated costs to governments and the society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is devoted to the development and commercialization of new photocatalytic oxidizing technology (PCO) that can remove hazardous or explosive gas levels from the ambient environment where manned operation is present. The target end users include coal, mining, and petroleum industries where disastrous gas explosion is one of the biggest threats. Through the whole project, Torrey Hills developed 3 prototypes with increasing processing capacities, tested a number of common hazardous gases and carried both in-house and field tests.  

This research attracted a range of industrial and media attention due to the promise in solving the critical day-to-day life-threatening issues.  The technology developed in the project has been named as a finalist in both the 2012 World Technology Awards competition (Energy Category) and 2013 Oil & Gas Award for Health & Safety Category.  Also due to this research work, Torrey Hills was awarded the prestigious 2013 SBA Tibbetts Award.  Major media coverage include Boston Globe, SF Chronicle, San Jose Mercury, Market Watch, Yahoo Finance, CCTV10 etc. Those industrial and media exposure helped improving public awareness of the safety issues and the technical progress among industrial and academic researchers.

By testing with a number of volatile organic gases (VOCs), Torrey Hills found the PCO technology has broad effect on oxidizing VOCs. The main chemical products are carbon dioxide with intermediate products including methanol and carbon monoxide.  Research also reveals that a number of factors can influence the conversion rates, including reactor temperature, humidity levels, catalysts species, photon wavelength and intensity, gas flow rates and number of circulation. The overall methane conversion rates were found to be between 0.025-0.04mg/(L.min). Economics study showed that the manufacturing costs of commercial units vary from a few thousands of dollars to hundreds thousands of dollars depending on the processing capability.

 This project also considerably developed the research interests and skills of its team members in the area of chemical engineering and environmental sustainability. For three of the team members with Ph.D. or M.S. degrees, this was their first project in an area related to environmental sustainability. These researchers may continue pursuing interests in this topic. For all the graduate students involved in the project, this was their first NSF sponsored project. They not only had opportunity to practice what they learned at school, but also gained knowledge of research funding structure which will surely help their future career development.

Torrey Hills also noticed a volatile trend in the overall world coal industry in the last 5 years.  Due to the world-wide price drop of natural gas, the production and price of coal have been steadily decreasing in recent years. This makes most coal industries cautious on spending on R&D, which increased the difficulties of commercialization of this project.
